channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Jackson Hole Journal: A New Frontier for the American West, in the Far East
item.description: On the outskirts of Beijing, more than 1,000 families have settled into a community modeled after an American frontier town, on streets with names like Aspen, Moose and Route 66.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: A new section of housing being built in Jackson Hole in Hebei Province, on the outskirts of Beijing, mimics the aesthetics of Jackson Hole, Wyo.

item.title: Joe Biden Urges Lawmakers in Ukraine to Fulfill Promise of Uprising
item.description: The American vice president, addressing the Parliament in Kiev, called on politicians to limit the power of business moguls and to reject self-interest.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER
item.media:description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. of the United States addressed the Ukrainian Parliament in Kiev on Tuesday from a lectern with a poster calling for the release of the Ukrainian pilot Nadiya V. Savchenko, who is being held in Russia.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Venezuela’s Opposition Shouldn’t Celebrate Yet
item.description: President Maduro’s party may have lost the legislative elections, but beware of the tricks up his sleeves.
item.dc:creator: RAÚL STOLK
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro attributed his party’s election defeat to right-wing forces at home and abroad that he accused of waging ‘‘economic war’’ on Venezuela.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Learning From Terrorism Past
item.description: Europe has lived through periods of rampant violence before, and survived.
item.dc:creator: BEPPE SEVERGNINI

item.title: Sinosphere: ISIS Extends Recruitment Efforts to China With New Chant
item.description: The Islamic State’s Mandarin-language recording, recently posted online, calls for Muslims to “take up weapons to fight.”
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG and ADAM WU
item.media:description: Islamic State fighters in the Syrian town of Tal Abyad, near the border with Turkey. There is no reliable information on how many Chinese have joined the Islamic State or other armed groups in Syria.

item.title: Beijing, With Red Alert for Smog in Full Force, Closes Schools and Limits Traffic
item.description: By Tuesday afternoon, walking through the city was like strolling through a coal mine, and the air quality index was still hazardous by American standards.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Heavy smog surrounding the West Lake in Hangzhou in Zhejiang Province in China on Tuesday. Because of industrial coal burning, Chinese cities regularly have among the world's worst air quality.

item.title: Oscar Pistorius Granted Bail Ahead of Sentencing
item.description: A lawyer for the Olympic athlete known as the Blade Runner said his client would appeal his murder conviction to South Africa’s highest court.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius at the North Gauteng High Court in Pretoria, South Africa, on Tuesday, before he was granted bail pending his sentencing for killing his girlfriend.

item.title: National Front Gets a Boost in French Regional Elections
item.description: With her party’s strong first-round showing on Sunday, and the traditional parties splintered, Marine Le Pen may be emerging as a serious presidential candidate.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: Posters in Calais, France, on Monday supporting Marine Le Pen, leader of the National Front, who led her party to a first-place finish in the first round of voting.

item.title: Despite Push for Cleaner Cars, Sheer Numbers Could Work Against Climate Benefits
item.description: With a billion additional cars coming to the world’s roads in coming decades, reducing the carbon footprint of autos faces an uphill journey.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: DAVID JOLLY
item.media:credit: Capucine Granier-Deferre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Renault-Nissan electric cars at Le Bourget, near Paris. Renault sells more electric vehicles in Europe than any other company — and with its Japanese alliance partner, Nissan, accounts for half the all-electric vehicles now on the world’s roads.

item.title: World Briefing: Peru: American Is Accused of Running Online Child-Sex Ring for Tourists
item.description: The American, Joshua Brown, 64, of New Hampshire, had been offering visitors sex with children for fees starting at $500.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Sinosphere: Beijing’s Red Alert for Pollution Rekindles Anger and Confusion
item.description: An attempt by one Chinese news outlet to point to New Delhi as having worse air quality invited derision from readers.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Commuters braving the bad air on Tuesday in Beijing, where the government has issued its first smog “red alert.”

item.title: World Briefing: Somalia: Maryland Man Who Fought for Shabab Surrenders After Fleeing
item.description: The American, Malik John, had surrendered earlier in the day on the edge of Barawe, about 135 miles southwest of the capital, Mogadishu.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Armenia: Referendum Approves Broader Powers for Prime Minister
item.description: Supporters say the move will improve stability, but opponents warn that it will entrench the governing party’s control over the former Soviet state.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Big Challenges Lie Ahead for a Delicate Winning Alliance in Venezuela
item.description: If Monday’s events are any indication, the opposition coalition in Venezuela could have difficulty holding together after its historic election victory as it tries to solve the country’s big problems.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: St.-Georges-de-l’Oyapock Journal: Linking Brazil to French Guiana, a Bridge for No One
item.description: More than four years after its completion, a bridge over the Oyapock River, hailed for its economic promise, still has not opened to pedestrians or vehicles.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: The bridge over the Oyapock River that connects St.-Georges, French Guiana, with Oiapoque, Brazil, was completed in 2011 but has never opened.

item.title: Exploiting Technology: Terrorists Mock Bids to End Use of Social Media
item.description: Politicians and even some technologists say Silicon Valley’s efforts to crack down on the use of social media and other technologies like encryption by terrorists have been toothless.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: NICOLE PERLROTH and MIKE ISAAC
item.media:description: On Twitter, 335 pro-Islamic State accounts carried simultaneous death threats against Jack Dorsey, above, and Dick Costolo, the current and former chief executives of Twitter.

item.title: News Analysis: U.S. Strategy Seeks to Avoid ISIS Prophecy
item.description: The Islamic State has focused on prophetic texts stating that Islam will be victorious after an apocalyptic battle to be set off once Western armies come to the region.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.media:description: An image from a propaganda video released by the Islamic State shows militants near Tikrit, Iraq, last year.

item.title: World Briefing: Italy: Iraqi With Terrorism Ties Is Arrested in Illegal Migration Case
item.description: The police identified the man as Majid Muhamad, 45, who served 10 years in an Italian prison on terrorism charges, and who was released a year ago.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Mariuccia Mandelli, Italian Fashion Designer, Dies at 90
item.description: The designer, who founded the fashion house Krizia in the mid-1950s, reigned for decades as “the godmother of classic Milanese fashion.”
item.dc:creator: MARGALIT FOX
item.media:description: Mariuccia Mandelli, center, surrounded by models at a Krizia spring collection in 1994.

item.title: World Briefing: Libya: Pentagon Confirms Death of an ISIS Leader
item.description: An Iraqi named Wissam Najm Abd Zayd al Zubaydi and known as Abu Nabil — was targeted Nov. 13 in a United States airstrike on a compound in the eastern city of Derna.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
